description: Numbers n such that n and n^2 combined use different digits.
comments: There are exactly 22 solutions in base 10.
references: M. Kraitchik, Mathematical Recreations, p. 48, Problem 12. - From _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 15 2013
maple: M:=1000;a1:=[]; a2:=[];for n from 1 to M do# are digits of n and n^2 distinct?t1:=convert(n,base,10);t2:=convert(n^2,base,10);s3:={op(t1),op(t2)};if nops(t1)+nops(t2) = nops(s3) then a1:=[op(a1),n]; a2:=[op(a2),n^2]; fi;od:a1; a2;# _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 15 2013
mathematica: Select[Range[10000], Intersection[IntegerDigits[ # ], IntegerDigits[ #^2]] == {} && Length[Union[IntegerDigits[ # ], IntegerDigits[ #^2]]] == Length[IntegerDigits[ # ]] + Length[IntegerDigits[ #^2]] &] (* _Tanya Khovanova_, Dec 25 2006 *)
crossrefs: Cf. A059931, A029783 (digits of n are not present in n^2), A112736 (numbers whose squares are exclusionary).
author: _Patrick De Geest_, Feb 15 2001
